summary: Email correspondence between defense attorney Bruce Barket and federal prosecutors regarding the preservation and review of photographs and surveillance video from Jeffrey Epstein's cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) following his death. The exchange highlights a prior miscommunication about the video and a defense request to verify other photographic evidence.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Attorney representing a client (likely Nicholas Tartaglione) requesting access to photos and surveillance video from Epstein's MCC cell after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Aida Leisenring
persons.context: Federal prosecutor copied on email correspondence regarding evidence preservation from Epstein's cell.

connections.description: Barket is an attorney making evidence requests related to Tartaglione's case, as indicated in the email subject.
Barket is corresponding with prosecutor Leisenring regarding evidence preservation from Epstein's cell.
Barket is corresponding with prosecutor Ricco regarding evidence preservation from Epstein's cell.
Both are federal prosecutors copied on the same email chain regarding evidence in the Epstein/Tartaglione matter.

events.title: Email Exchange on MCC Cell Evidence
events.description: Email correspondence between defense attorney Bruce Barket and federal prosecutors regarding the preservation and review of photographs and surveillance video from Jeffrey Epstein's cell at MCC.

events.title: Prosecutor Letter on Video Preservation
events.description: Prosecutors filed a letter on the docket stating that surveillance video from Epstein's MCC cell was preserved upon request and they are working to obtain a copy.

locations: One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Defense attorney Bruce Barket was seeking photographs and surveillance video taken of Jeffrey Epstein's cell at MCC around the time of the initial response to the cell and after Epstein was removed.
There was a prior miscommunication between the defense and prosecution regarding whether the surveillance video had been preserved.
The prosecution confirmed on December 19, 2019, that the video was preserved and they were working to obtain a copy for review.
The evidence request is connected to the case of Nicholas Tartaglione, as indicated in the email subject line.
